												I have to admit, I have some reservations about recommending this game. It's a beautiful old school point and click adventure game that keeps VERY true to its inspiration. The game looks nice and has an interesting, if not necessarily stellar, story, lots of puzzles, and loads of inventor items to fondle. If you like older adventure games like Lucasarts' classics than you should probably just go ahead and get this game. It doesn't quite have the humor those older games had, but the gameplay is much the same. Unfortunately, many of the irritating aspects of those older games are very present here. Many of the puzzles require a good deal of "inventory alchemy," so you'll often find yourself spending time listening to the main character repeating quips like "What am I thinking" a dozen times in a row as you try combining every one of your items with every other item in an attempt to figure out what arcane combination will yield a helpful result. Puzzles are also rather hit-or-miss. Most are fairly logical, but as you get closer to the end of the game they become increasingly convoluted until virtually all sense of reason is lost. I'm not ashamed to admit that there is simply no way I would have figured out that last few segments without a guide. If you can put up with these irritations, than there is a good game here, but it is very much a diamond in the rough.A note to achievement hunters: This game has some rather odd achievements for a point and click adventure game. First off, you will have to play the game multiple times to unlock everything (which I don't see any point in for this type of game). There are also a lot of achievements for performing arbitrary and time wasting actions like "click on this thing 10 times in a row." There is however, one interesting achievement I wish I had seen earlier. You can earn an achievement for using the "Hotspot Highlighter" less then 50 times in the course of a single play through.

Suddenly you'll find yourself wandering back and forth repeatedly between the same few screens over and over frustratedly clicking everything in your inventory and speaking to the same characters for a thousand times to get that one oddball thing you missed.  This seems to build up to an incredible degree near the end of the game with what I found to frankly be the most bizarre puzzle solutions ever.  The spot near the end where you put the wizard hat upside down in the chandelier and dump a decanter full of wine into it...I was shouting "WHY WOULD YOU DO THIS???" at the screen.  It only sort of makes sense after you're already through the end of that puzzle, but come on, really?  When you reach the final "level", things get a little more straight forward again, but that's mostly due to the fact that you have almost no inventory and there's not a lot of things that are clickable or screens to move between.  In spite of this, I'd still say to give this a play through.  The story made it worthwhile in the end and I'm looking forward to giving the sequel, Memoria, a try.

												The Dark Eye: Chains of Satinav is a very beatiful to look at game, quite a bit less fun to play at times, with a decent story.The artwork for this game is gorgeous.  Every visual is a quality painted backdrop with animated characters.  Music fits the setting, nothing memorable or catchy but not at all unpleasant to listen to.  If this game had any less of a beautiful front it might be easily dismissed, because at times the puzzles are just plain bad or un-fun.The game is kind it that it will let you (and I suggest you do) highlight interactables on-screen as well as highlight correct item combinations, but quite a few times item combinations or puzzle solutions are downright illogical or confusing.  Nobody likes mashing every item against every other in your inventory or against the objects on screen, and sometimes that's what you have to do.  It doesn't help that the game throws quite a few deliberate red herrings into the mix.  One notable instance is where you can put an item into a 'broken' and 'unbroken' state via magic.  There is no need to break the object to solve the puzzle, nor is there any standard for having items be breakable arbitrarilty (the character even states '(Friend name) doesn't like it when I break things.'!).  Its just there to purposefully confuse you.  Sometimes interactables may seem unacquireable or useless because the player is denied interaction, but then they become acquirable later for arbitrary reasons,  At another point, the game forces a story-irrelevant zone transition from a zone the player has explored to a new one, and the player must manually backtrack to the previous zone in order to solve a new puzzle because the story-irrelevant transition forced him to walk past a required item. The story is okay, it definitely starts out rough and a little boring but thankfully gets much better as it goes on.  I like to avoid spoilers so as always I don't say much.  Voice acting is decent, and characters are fairly distinct and again some of the later ones are more interesting along with the story.   Sometimes voice acted lines and subtitles dont match up or even give conflicting information, which can be confusing.  The game's cosmology and setting are moderately interesting, again, better as the game goes on.Point and click games are hard to say much about, usually.   If you can get past the rough start and don't mind a few gamefaqs for the stupid puzzles then its a fair-quality game with amazing visual work.  Its been on sale for as low as $7-ish before and I clocked in 10 or so hours of gameplay.  It sets up for an arguably much better sequel as well, and quality point and click are hard to come by so I think this one will get my recommendation.

												I play classic point & click adventure games a lot and I also played The Dark Eye RPG in the pen & paper version in my youth. I cannot remember all facts and stories of the world Aventuria in which Chains of Satinav plays. Anyway I do not care whether the world is 100% reflected by the game. Nonetheless, the game designers have done a remarkable job to feel like being in Aventuria. And also to create a really dense atmosphere with characters that you learn to love during gameplay. Like many Daedalic adventures the story is not a simple good vs. evil plot. Below the obvious surface (evil seer, ravens, dark creatures ...) one may notice thoughts about being determined in life though people don't support you or in general whether ends justifies the means (lies).An important part of adventures are the puzzles and Chains of Satinav has a lot of good ones (especially in the faerie world). Unfortunately there are also times when the puzzles become easier again. Why? Although I appreciate that Chains of Satinav takes you to many places, the problem here is that some of them are very restricted. You cannot go further until you solve that handful of puzzles which makes it too easy sometimes and makes the game feel too 'vertical'. What was really refreshing however was the idea of having a destruction and (later) a repair spell in your repertoire which distinguishes the adventures from others a little bit. Those spells are also really well woven into the other puzzle sequences.The world is drawn by wonderful fantastic sceneries which fit very well to the various places the adventure takes you to. The animations could be smoother though. The voice acting is done very well at least in the German version I played - whereas the music is let's say unobstrusive and could be diversified more and emphasize some events better.A very underrated adventure in my opinion. All in all a game that I really enjoyed a lot. I will miss Geron and Nuri.

												Chains of Satinav is about a sassy dude who's constantly down on his luck, untill he must capture a fairy and everything gets much worse. Some of that may sound familiar... But it's hardly a bad thing.This game is the second time I made a real effort to play a P&C Adventure, after I have No Mouth, And I Must Scream. Broken Age doesn't count, because it's short and unfinished at this time.I'm putting this up front, Chains of Satinav is a great game, and it's baffling nobody ever talks about it. It's set in a world that now crosses over with multiple games from different genres, so there's a ton of worldbuilding through conversation and observation. The conversations themselves feel very real for a basic go-through-all-the-options dialogue tree system, mostly in part to the voice acting. The puzzles can be difficult, but make perfect sense in comparison to standard combine-items-to-see-what-works fare. Sometimes it makes use of options you don't really know are there, but the game does tell you what you need for the situation, you just gotta figure out how to get it. Sometimes you need to revisit characters after a puzzle portion is solved to try and advance the puzzle itself, which was annoying in that one section with a bunch of other characters fighting for screen time, but it never get's harder than that thankfully. No timed item puzzles or unsolvables. No deaths.It's a really solid adventure game with endearing characters, sensible but difficult puzzles and a sequel I should get back to, as it looks like they've improved on the presentation even more. Memoria is the name, just to confuse people, but it is a direct sequel to this story and would spoil the ending almost immediately otherwise.The only problem I had overall was the janky animations. It's the only thing that kept me from playing it through when I got it. Don't let it keep you away though, because it is definitely worth it.
